name: NPR
text:
In Montgomery, Ohio, the annual Fourth of July parade is a long honored tradition.

To keep it up during the pandemic, they've decided to do a "reverse parade" this year â€” where the units are stationery and the spectators drive through.

name: NPR
text:
Photographer Salgu Wissmath says gender dysphoria is "sorely misunderstood by society."

Using deeply intimate portraits, they set out to document some of the experiences of trans and nonbinary people â€” through a queer lens.

name: NPR
text:

text:

text:

name: NPR
text:
Talking about death makes many of us uncomfortable, so we donâ€™t plan for it.

But the reality is that end-of-life planning is important â€” and even a small amount of planning ensures our final wishes are honored.

Here's some advice for getting started.

name: NPR
text: Low-wage workers fought hard to win higher minimum wages in recent years, but businesses are arguing the increases should be delayed to help them recover from pandemic shutdowns. Workers say that's unacceptable after their front-line efforts. @wamu885 https://t.co/loVfhh22xc

text:

name: NPR
text:
A total of 32 states currently aren't doing enough coronavirus testing to achieve mitigation, researchers say.

"The surges we're seeing in large parts of the country are due in part because those states opened up too quickly â€¦ and they lacked testing."

name: NPR
text:

name: NPR
text: Some school districts are reassessing their relationships with local police departments. But schools' use of security guards to police student behavior, even in the youngest grades, also can result in troubling incidents. @KUOW https://t.co/zMSSkGlGbU
